rev.comment: add section headings for other specific controversies to reflect the traffic accident doesn't look like the biggest controversial

===Police misconduct===

===Scott Olsen injured===
On October 25th, Scott Olsen, a former [[United States Marine Corps|Marine]] and [[Iraq War]] veteran, and a member of [[Veterans for Peace]], suffered a [[bone fracture|skull fracture]] caused by a shooting [[projectile]] that witnesses believed was a tear gas or smoke canister fired by the police.<ref name="Reuters Olson">{{cite news
On October 25th, Scott Olsen, a former [[United States Marine Corps|Marine]] and [[Iraq War]] veteran, and a member of [[Veterans for Peace]], suffered a [[bone fracture|skull fracture]] caused by a shooting [[projectile]] that witnesses believed was a tear gas or smoke canister fired by the police.<ref name="Reuters Olson">{{cite news

Line 145: Line 145:
|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/oct/26/occupy-oakland-veteran-critical-condition |accessdate=October 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Marine Veteran Injured by Non-Lethal Rounds at Occupy Oakland |publisher=Veterans Today |date=October 26, 2011 |url= http://www.veteranstoday.com/2011/10/26/marine-veteran-injured-by-non-lethal-rounds-at-occupy-oakland/ |accessdate=October 26, 2011}}</ref> At least two other protesters were injured.<ref name=rt261011/> The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] and [[National Lawyers Guild]] are calling for an investigation into the use of excessive force by Oakland police.<ref name="return">{{cite news |last=Bender |first=Kristen |title=Occupy Oakland protesters return downtown to claim Frank Ogawa Plaza |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_19197518 |accessdate=October 27, 2011 |newspaper=Oakland Tribune |date=October 26, 2011}}</ref>
|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/oct/26/occupy-oakland-veteran-critical-condition |accessdate=October 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Marine Veteran Injured by Non-Lethal Rounds at Occupy Oakland |publisher=Veterans Today |date=October 26, 2011 |url= http://www.veteranstoday.com/2011/10/26/marine-veteran-injured-by-non-lethal-rounds-at-occupy-oakland/ |accessdate=October 26, 2011}}</ref> At least two other protesters were injured.<ref name=rt261011/> The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] and [[National Lawyers Guild]] are calling for an investigation into the use of excessive force by Oakland police.<ref name="return">{{cite news |last=Bender |first=Kristen |title=Occupy Oakland protesters return downtown to claim Frank Ogawa Plaza |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_19197518 |accessdate=October 27, 2011 |newspaper=Oakland Tribune |date=October 26, 2011}}</ref>
â
Shortly before 1am on November 3, Oakland resident and anarchist Scott Campbell was shot by police using a [[Non-lethal_weapon#Ammunition|less-lethal round]] while he was filming a stationary line of police in riot gear, hours after the [[2011 Oakland general strike]]. The apparently-unprovoked shooting was documented by the resulting point-of-view video from Campbell's own camera.<ref name=Cambell>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57321440/experts-occupy-vid-shows-excessive-force/ Experts: "Occupy" video shows excessive force]</ref> Geoffrey Alpert, a criminal justice professor from the University of South Carolina said watching a video of the incident left him "astonished, amazed and embarrassed" and that "unless there's something we don't know, that's one of the most outrageous uses of a firearm that I've ever seen."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19284774|accessdate=Nov 7, 2011}}</ref>
+
===Scott Campbell shooting===
  +
Shortly before 1am on November 3, Oakland resident Scott Campbell was shot by police using a [[Non-lethal_weapon#Ammunition|less-lethal round]] while he was filming a stationary line of police in riot gear, hours after the [[2011 Oakland general strike]]. The apparently-unprovoked shooting was documented by the resulting point-of-view video from Campbell's own camera.<ref name=Cambell>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57321440/experts-occupy-vid-shows-excessive-force/ Experts: "Occupy" video shows excessive force]</ref> Geoffrey Alpert, a criminal justice professor from the University of South Carolina said watching a video of the incident left him "astonished, amazed and embarrassed" and that "unless there's something we don't know, that's one of the most outrageous uses of a firearm that I've ever seen."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19284774|accessdate=Nov 7, 2011}}</ref>
  +
===Kayvan Sabeghi injured during arrest==
Kayvan Sabeghi, a former [[United States Army Rangers|U.S. Army Ranger]] who served in the [[Iraq War]] and the [[War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)|War in Afghanistan]], was seriously injured while being arrested by police that evening. He was walking away from the late evening protest when he was stopped by police. <ref>{{cite news|last=Gabbatt|first=Adam|title=Occupy Oakland: second Iraq war veteran injured after police clashes|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/04/occupy-oakland-second-veteran-injured|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref> The organization [[Iraq Veterans Against the War]] issued a statement saying that "police struck Sabeghi with nightsticks on his hands, shoulders, ribs and back, and that in addition to a lacerated [[spleen]] he suffered from internal bleeding." After 18 hours of being denied medical treatment while in police custody he was transferred to [[Highland Hospital (Oakland, California)|Highland Hospital]] and put into the intensive care unit. <ref name=kayvan_reuters>{{cite news|last=Randewich|first=Noel|title=Army veteran injured in Oakland clashes with police|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/05/us-protests-oakland-veteran-idUSTRE7A37A820111105|accessdate=6 November 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=4 November 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|title=Kayvan Sabeghi Injured: Second Iraq war vet hurt during Oakland clash with police|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/05/kayvan-sabeghi-injured_n_1077806.html|accessdate=5 November 2011|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=5 November 2011}}</ref>
Kayvan Sabeghi, a former [[United States Army Rangers|U.S. Army Ranger]] who served in the [[Iraq War]] and the [[War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)|War in Afghanistan]], was seriously injured while being arrested by police that evening. He was walking away from the late evening protest when he was stopped by police. <ref>{{cite news|last=Gabbatt|first=Adam|title=Occupy Oakland: second Iraq war veteran injured after police clashes|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/04/occupy-oakland-second-veteran-injured|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref> The organization [[Iraq Veterans Against the War]] issued a statement saying that "police struck Sabeghi with nightsticks on his hands, shoulders, ribs and back, and that in addition to a lacerated [[spleen]] he suffered from internal bleeding." After 18 hours of being denied medical treatment while in police custody he was transferred to [[Highland Hospital (Oakland, California)|Highland Hospital]] and put into the intensive care unit. <ref name=kayvan_reuters>{{cite news|last=Randewich|first=Noel|title=Army veteran injured in Oakland clashes with police|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/05/us-protests-oakland-veteran-idUSTRE7A37A820111105|accessdate=6 November 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=4 November 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|title=Kayvan Sabeghi Injured: Second Iraq war vet hurt during Oakland clash with police|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/05/kayvan-sabeghi-injured_n_1077806.html|accessdate=5 November 2011|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=5 November 2011}}</ref>
  +
===Allegations of prisoner mistreatment===
Journalist Susie Cagle was arrested in the early hours of November 3, jailed, and ultimately charged with a misdemeanor. Cagle subsequently reported having observed mistreatment of protestors during their imprisonment.<ref name=Cagle>[http://www.alternet.org/story/152990/police_state_in_oakland_one_reporter%27s_arrest_contradicts_official_story/?page=entire]</ref>
Journalist Susie Cagle was arrested in the early hours of November 3, jailed, and ultimately charged with a misdemeanor. Cagle subsequently reported having observed mistreatment of protestors during their imprisonment.<ref name=Cagle>[http://www.alternet.org/story/152990/police_state_in_oakland_one_reporter%27s_arrest_contradicts_official_story/?page=entire]</ref>
